The program to achieve these purposes will attempt to operate in typical school
situations using the regular teachers and resources of the system. Adequate special-
lized and technical assistance will be provided as needed for planning, producing
and evaluating the work. As new assumptions are made and new educational pro¬
cedures developed and evaluated, safeguards will be constantly considered to make
sure that each child will have a good program of education.
Closed-circuit television facilities will be extended to all the schools of the county
as follows:
1 . Plans for the 1956-57 school year
The T. V. center at the Board of Education office, two senior high schools and
six elementary schools in Hagerstown, the Washington County Museum of Fine
Arts, and the Washington County Free Library are to be linked by coaxial cable
in the first circuit. Telecasting is scheduled to begin with the opening of school
on September 10. (6,000 pupils)
2. Plans for the 1957-58 school year
Extension of circuits to include two high schools and thirteen elementary schools
in the Hagerstown area, September 1957. (6,210 additional pupils)
3. Plans for the 1958-59 school year
Extension of circuits to include all the other county schools, five high schools
and twenty elementary schools, September 1958. (5,790 additional pupils)
A six weeks summer workshop will be organized to develop the initial program in the
use of television for instruction.
